title: Cat. 84  Fragment of a Cup, late 1st century B.C./1st century A.D.
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Fragment of a Cup  
Late 1st century B.C./1st century A.D.  
Roman  
Glass, mosaic glass technique; 4 × 5.4 × 1 cm (1 5/8 × 2 1/8 × 3/8 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1949.1238

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Transparent aquamarine, translucent amethyst, and opaque white, yellow, and brick-red glass. Cup fragment fabricated by the mosaic glass technique, tooled, and polished. The fragment preserves a segment of the outsplayed rim and double carinated profile. The mosaic pattern is formed from sections of two canes: one in an aquamarine ground with a yellow spiral and central dot. The second, more predominant cane in an amethyst ground, a white central dot with a concentric red ring surrounded by a ring of nine yellow dots in turn surrounded by a thin white ring.

The longest edge preserves the rim; three sides are broken and all retain a light-brown incrustation. One edge has a thick weathering crust and some brilliant iridescence; the interior is repolished.  
Sidney Goldstein

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 84 Fragment of a Cup, late 1st century B.C./1st century A.D.

</section>
